threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: For 1957, Ford debuted new larger cars with an additional inch of wheelbase length and a modified chassis to give a generally lower look over the 52-56 generation. The I6 and a variety of Y-block V8 variants were offered as drivetrain choices. Other new features included a transistorized radio and several safety options including seatbelts and recessed dashboard controls. Ford moved 1.6 million cars for the model year, allowing them to top Chevrolet for the first time since 1935. However the soon to be famous '57 Chevy had more popularity with the teenage/youth crowd as its smaller size and lighter weight resulted in better performance, and the SBC V8 was easier to modify for power than the Y-block which lacked factory performance parts. Ford's emphasis on safety was also considered uncool by young men. The '57 Fords also had less than outstanding body integrity and assembly quality, and quickly rusted or leaked water. Consequently not many of them or the even worse '57 Plymouth have survived, although the quality control issues were largely resolved in the next two model years.

>>26118018
$481 shipped from RockAuto for a new Master Cylinder, calipers, rotors, pads, and all soft lines.
That's the worst-case scenario, literally a half day of work.
If you're not averted to working on cars, a brake fluid leak isn't scary, it's part of an extremely simple and serviceable hydraulic system that barely varies from one vehicle to the next and is usually inexpensive and quick to service.

Of course that means that $600 Lexus could end up being an $1100 Lexus by the time you've worked out just the brakes.
That's before you even consider working on the valve cover leak which can only be ignored if it's mild, if it's in any way significant you gotta take care of it, and I promise that job won't be fun or fast, picrel.
They don't mention the tires in the Ad, but from the shitty photos they look bad, so add on another $300-$400 for some of the cheapest sluts at Walmart or Discount Tire, that'd be the installed price on those $60 Chink tires you see so many of these days.
Bare minimum give the heap an oil change because it's safe to assume nobody else has, the stealership definitely did not.
A PH3614 is only $4 at Walmart, the cheapest 5qt bottle of oil you'll find there will usually be $20-$25.
Watch for sales from auto parts stores, it's not weird to find a deal on 5qts + oil filter + air filter for say $25, or with a drain pan and a roll of shop towels for $30, that sort of thing.

With tires and brakes and an oil change done, then it's plenty safe to drive!
Hopefully nothing else turns out to be wrong with it, it is almost 30 years old.
That is to say, even if nothing else is wrong, something else will be soon.
That's $900-$1500 to safely drive this $600 Lexus for a few weeks until the next thing breaks, assuming you totally ignore the valve cover gasket leaking, and do all of the work yourself.

Did I mention that this engine has a timing belt? Guess you'll be fixing that valve cover leak anyway!

>Don't buy a 29 year old Lexus for $600.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Yearly update for this car. Owned this thing for just over two years now and put 30,000 miles on it. The only things i've replaced are my turbo coolant line flex joints and a nine year old battery. Zero oil consumption issues. Done basic things like coil packs/spark plugs myself. Oil changes are just as quick and easy as my Civic. Catless downpipes (a bear to install), very light OTS tune, springs, spacers, and bought an OEM carbon interior set for it. Taking the interior apart wasn't too hard.

I see BMW S63 threads in here all the time, with quite a bit of incorrect info. These cars are very reliable if you take proper care of them, and are not hard to work on yourself with limited wrenching knowledge. The 2012-2019 M6 and 2012-2016 (F10) M5 were all fitted with the S63TU (Technical Update), which has some real quality of life improvements over the earlier S63 found in the 2009-2013 (E70) X5M. These early S63s don't suffer nearly as badly as the infamous pre-TU N63.

>>26124341
>I can afford to pay 30k up front in cash but i would prefer not to. Can I get an auto loan from my credit union

You can go talk to your credit union in advance of buying a car to see how much of a loan you can get. The credit union then issues you a letter saying you are pre-approved for a loan of X amount at Y percent interest provided that the purchase is for a new car. This gives you a lot of flexibiliy since you can go to a variety of dealerships.

You shouldn't let the dealer know that you have a preapproved letter of credit as that kills most of your negotiation advantages. Dealers make a lot of money from financing, so a customer that pays cash is less desirable.

It's unfortunate that the Fed keeps on issuing basis point increases in the interest rates.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonathanponciano/2022/11/02/fed-raises-rates-another-75-basis-points-further-pushing-borrowing-costs-to-highest-level-since-great-recession/

The current speculation is that the Fed will raise interest rates from a roughly floating range of 4.25 to 4.50 to be 4.75 to 5.00 in the first half of 2023.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
The ill-starred R-body cars (Chrysler New Yorker and Newport and Dodge St. Regis) arrived in fall 1978 from a manufacturer that was at death's door. Not really new cars, they were just Chrysler's 16 year old B-body platform with a new look and were nominal replacements for the C-body platform. Quality control was feeble even by the low standards of this era and misaligned body panels and rust spots were common on brand-new vehicles. Detroit mayor Coleman Young was invited to test drive a New Yorker off the assembly line only to find the car wouldn't start. There was no money to promote them with all advertising resources going to the more important L-bodies and new Chrysler chairman Lee Iaccoca decided to produce the R-bodies (approved by the previous Ricardo regime) largely because the tooling had already been bought and paid for so the cars had to be produced just long enough to amortize the tooling costs.

Moderately good 1979 sales crashed in 1980-81 with the second energy crisis and uncertainly over Chrysler's future, after which the R-bodies were laid to rest with little mourning. A Plymouth version, the Gran Fury, was added for '80 largely as a concession to the fleet market, which comprised the vast majority of Dodge and Plymouth R-body sales.

I was thinking pretty much the exact same thing. I would word it slightly differently though. I think a lot of stuff has measurably changed, but I totally agree that none of those changes are significant improvements.
I can think so so many /o/ related examples. I'd say fuel economy has measurably changed for the better, but it came at the cost of increased complexity, increased expense to build and repair, and decreased reliability, so it may not be a net improvement depending on an individual's priorities. It only benefits people who want to drive a new or nearly new car anyway, and will be driving a lot of miles / burning a lot of fuel in a short amount of time, in my estimation. Besides better fuel economy, more maximum power in some cases, and of course whiz-bang gimmicks like touch screens, back-up cameras and tire pressure monitors that I could easily add to my old car anyway if I wanted to, I really don't see any ways that cars have significantly improved over the last 20 years. To my mind, the decrease in reliability caused by the added complexity has caused a net decrease in desirability.

>>26122567
Carrying dead mens baggage doesn't bring them back but if you want to learn wrenching that's not a bad choice and everyone starts somewhere.

Parts are easy and the first thing to do would be clean and detail it. "Worth it" financially? Not for the car but for the experience. Don't expect a great outcome from a first project but if you're patient (and get good at forums because they are the key fucking source for old car info) you can make a reasonable machine.

Chasing some ideal performance is silly because the street is not a race track. Ignore young people even if you are one. Mechanics and old cars are mentoring cultures and very cool. A car need not be great to be fun and you can always sell it later if useful. Getting into wrenching is worth far more than any one vehicle because it makes you independent for life.

Montes will remain collectible and if you remove turbo etc for some reason just box it all nicely (not fucking cardboard) after hitting the parts with Boeshield then cling wrapping them.

>Head to rockauto and basically add 1 of everything to the cart and figure out if that's a number you can live with spending

^ALWAYS do this even though you know you can get most parts as if you can't afford a particular TOY then you don't need that TOY. I have many toys because I plan like that.

Never guess when you can know.
Never substitute wishful thinking for knowledge
Never go shopping hungry and never marry what you can pimp.

I would give that car a home though after cleaning it up (cosmetics are fucking key, engine parts are easy) I'd sell it then buy another Harley.

I forgot to mention, C2s back then were just a "used car", nobody cared about collectability back then. They were also hella thirsty at a time when gas prices were the highest they had ever been, so people were getting rid of them as fast as possible. Totally different market from todays world. Lastly, a 10 year old car back then was considered dead and buried, if you didn't basically rebuild it top to bottom it was a pile of garbage because the lack of fuel injection meant everything would get carbon deposited to shit and things like fuel lines would all go to shit and need to be replaced in a short time. Rubber things like bushings were also short lived trash as were interior upholstery and anything plastic. Today, you can get a 25 year old C5 that looks dealership fresh. Try that with a C2 back then and the best kept one would have one foot in the grave.
